awd_titl_txt: Support for Institutes and Research Groups on Qualitative and Multi-Method  Research: 2018-2020
awd_abstract_narration:
The Institute for Qualitative and Multi-Method Research is a two-week meeting held each summer at Syracuse University. The Institute promotes the teaching and application of qualitative research methods in political science and other social science disciplines. Given the inferential leverage that using multiple analytic techniques can deliver, the Institute's instructors and participants, and thus its pedagogy, are also strongly concerned with how qualitative methods undergird and complement alternative analytic approaches. The current proposal requests NSF's support for the 14th, 15th and 16th iterations of the Institute (2015-2017) and its associated Research Group. The Research Group is a two-day authors' workshop that meets at least once during each Institute's two-week duration. 

The Institute is now firmly established as the premier venue for intensive instruction on, training to conduct, and preparation to teach qualitative and multi-method research. By June 2014, over 1,600 graduate students and junior faculty will have received instruction on advanced qualitative methods at the Institute. 

The Institute has also had a direct and beneficial influence on the development of the qualitative and multi-methods canon, especially in political science. Early versions of books and articles developing, disseminating and/or using qualitative methods have been presented and discussed at the Institute. "Road-testing" forthcoming work at the Institute gives authors an unparalleled opportunity to receive valuable feedback and criticism from an audience with diverse epistemic commitments and substantive interests. Interchange at the Institute has also resulted in collaborative writing projects among faculty and participants, and has stimulated new methodological research by both groups. One of the primary missions of the Research Group is to encourage and empower young scholars to publish in the field of methodology, thus enhancing and expanding the core canon of published research on qualitative and multi-method research. 

The Institute provides high-level, carefully designed instruction for a large and diverse group of attendees drawn from a wide national and, increasingly, international constituency. The Institute's contribution to improving methodological training in the social sciences has resulted in more rigorous and methodologically self-conscious research. Its deliberate outreach to scholars from developing countries has the potential to induce an especially powerful multiplier effect when those participants go on to teach what they have learned at their home institution, thereby extending the Institute's reach to multiple locations around the globe
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Institute for Qualitative and Multi-Method Research (IQMR) is a two-week training program held each summer at Syracuse University.  The Institute promotes the teaching and application of qualitative research methods, and their combination with complementary analytic techniques, in political science and cognate disciplines.  The canon on qualitative and multi-method research has expanded dramatically over the last two decades, and will likely continue to grow at a rapid pace. Through convening top methodologists, and training nearly 3,000 early-career social scientists since its inception, the Institute has fueled this expansion, developing and disseminating new analytic tools for practicing researchers.

The grant being reported on supported the 2018, 2019, 2021 (online), and 2022 Institutes, in which a total of 744 graduate students and junior faculty participated.  In lieu of the 2020 Institute, which was canceled due to the public health emergency, IQMR organized a limited number of online activities including faculty panels, research design discussion groups, as well as an online webinar introducing data management plans (DMPs) and approximately 20 DMP consultations.

In 2018, 2019, 2021 (online), and 2022 the NSF's support for the Institute directly contributed to a broad range of benefits including:

  • an intellectual benefit for participants of intensive training in qualitative methods and multi-method research;
  • an enrichment benefit for participants from sharing, receiving feedback on, and improving research designs for ongoing and future qualitative and multi-method work, as well as from learning to analyze and constructively critique those of others;
  • a networking benefit for participants by providing formal and informal opportunities for them to interact, collaborate, and build valuable and productive relationships, thereby fostering a community of scholars who employ qualitative and multi-method research designs, .
  • a multiplier benefit, as participants go on to teach courses in qualitative and multi-method research; and
  • a demonstration benefit, raising the profile of qualitative and multi-method research and highlighting the ongoing need for systematic training in their application.

Through producing these benefits, the Institute inspired and empowered the development and teaching of valuable new methodological approaches and sparked productive methodological debates, challenging a new generation of scholars to advance the field in productive directions.

NSF's support for the Institute has been a vital component in its success. Most directly, the current grant contributed to the awarding, through a competitive process,  of more than a dozen fellowships to attend the institute each year. These slots were in great demand, with an average of more than 10 applicants for each available slot. In addition, separate competitive application tracks enabled attendance by early career researchers from scholarly institutions in Africa and the Middle East/North Africa. NSF's support also served as an indispensable external meritocratic indicator, helping to persuade academic departments and research centers to make separate nominations of participants to the institute.

NSF's grant also supported the associated Research Group in Qualitative and Multi-Method Analysis, an authors' workshop that typically meets during the weekend between the two weeks of the Institute. One of the authors' workshop missions is to help younger scholars step into the role of publishing actively in the field of methodology, thereby adding to the core canon of published research on which the wider academic community draws. The workshop has also been centrally important in developing manuscripts that have been submitted for review to, and ultimately published in two Cambridge University Press book series: "Strategies for Social Inquiry," and the newer "Methods for Social Inquiry." 


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Colin Elman
